title: Steele dossier
deleted: [[Max Boot]]<ref name="Boot_8/1/2020"/> described what he sees as more "evidence of Trump's subservience to Putin", and he tied it to new government confirmations of rumors about Trump's alleged "dalliances with Russian women during visits to Moscow" that leave "him open to blackmail", rumors mentioned in the 2020 [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] report:<ref name="Senate_8/18/2020"/> "This is the first confirmation from any branch of the U.S. government that rumors of Russian kompromat on Trump — a central feature of the infamous Steele Dossier — may have some basis in fact."<ref name="Boot_8/1/2020">{{cite web | last=Boot | first=Max | title=More evidence of Trump's subservience to Putin - and we still don't know why | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=August 1, 2020 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/09/01/more-evidence-trumps-subservience-putin-we-still-dont-know-why/ | access-date=September 3, 2020}}</ref>

title: Steele dossier
deleted: [[Max Boot]]<ref name="Boot_8/1/2020"/> described what he sees as more "evidence of Trump's subservience to Putin", and he tied it to new government confirmations of rumors about Trump's alleged "dalliances with Russian women during visits to Moscow" that leave "him open to blackmail", rumors mentioned in the 2020 [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] report:<ref name="Senate_8/18/2020"/> "This is the first confirmation from any branch of the U.S. government that rumors of Russian kompromat on Trump — a central feature of the infamous Steele Dossier — may have some basis in fact."<ref name="Boot_8/1/2020">{{cite web | last=Boot | first=Max | title=More evidence of Trump's subservience to Putin - and we still don't know why | website=[[The Washington Post]] | date=August 1, 2020 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/09/01/more-evidence-trumps-subservience-putin-we-still-dont-know-why/ | access-date=September 3, 2020}}</ref>

title: Steele dossier
deleted: A 25-second "pee tape" video of the purported occurrence has been in circulation since at least January 25, 2019. [[Ashley Feinberg]] has written extensively about it and all the reports and sources which have discussed and analyzed it. She describes it as believable but fake.<ref name="Feinberg_9/25/2019">{{cite web | last=Feinberg | first=Ashley | title=The Pee Tape Is Real, but It's Fake | website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/09/inside-the-convincing-fake-trump-pee-tape.html | date=September 25, 2019 | access-date=September 27, 2019}}</ref>

While many people, including Russians, do not believe the "pee tape" incident happened, [[Stanislav Belkovsky]], Russian [[political analyst]] and a founder and director of the National Strategy Institute, disagrees: "Prostitutes around the city say the 'golden shower' orgy story is true".<ref name="Nemtsova_1/20/2017">{{cite web | last=Nemtsova | first=Anna | title=She Met Donald Trump at the Moscow Ritz (Not That Way!) | website=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=January 20, 2017 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/01/20/she-met-donald-trump-at-the-moscow-ritz-not-that-way | access-date=December 1, 2019}}</ref>

title: Steele dossier
deleted: A footnote in the Mueller Report suggests that Trump may have heard that Russia had incriminating tapes of his behavior.  On October 30, 2016, Michael Cohen exchanged a series of text messages with Giorgi Rtskhiladze, a businessman who had worked with Cohen on Trump's real estate projects. Rtskhiladze reported that he had successfully stopped the "flow of tapes from Russia but not sure if there's anything else. Just so you know … ." Rtskhiladze told investigators that these were compromising tapes of Trump. Cohen told investigators he spoke to Trump about the issue. Rtskhiladze later told investigators "he was told the tapes were fake, but he did not communicate that to Cohen."<ref name="Kessler_4/24/2019"/> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reported that "Rtskhiladze's description of the tapes' content tracks with the unverified information included in the Steele dossier".<ref name="Stuart_4/18/2019">{{cite web | last=Stuart | first=Tessa | title=Here's What the Mueller Report Says About the Pee Tape | website=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=April 18, 2019 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/pee-tape-trump-mueller-report-823755/ | access-date=November 6, 2019}}</ref>

Before the 2013 Miss Universe contest in Moscow, Trump was accompanied on his visit to the Las Vegas club "Act" by Crocus Group owner Aras Agalarov and his son Emin, who was involved in the invitation to share "dirt" on Clinton at the [[Trump Tower meeting]].<ref name="Sheth_3/14/2018">{{cite web | last=Sheth | first=Sonam | title=House Intelligence Democrats want to question the Ritz-Carlton in Moscow about the most salacious allegation in the Trump-Russia dossier | website=[[Business Insider]] | date=March 14, 2018 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/house-democrats-want-to-question-ritz-carlton-moscow-trump-steele-dossier-2018-3 | access-date=April 11, 2020}}</ref> The Agalarovs were also linked to knowledge of Trump's alleged sexual activities in Russia, both in St. Petersburg and the Moscow Ritz Carlton. The dossier's sources reported that Aras Agalarov "would know most of the details of what the Republican presidential candidate had got up to" in St. Petersburg.<ref name="Bertrand_11/10/2017"/> In 2013, when Trump stayed at the Ritz Carlton hotel, "multiple sources", reported that the offer to "send five women to Trump's hotel room that night"<ref name="Corn_Isikoff_3/8/2018"/> came from a Russian who was accompanying Emin Agalarov".<ref name="Raju_Herb_11/10/2017"/> A footnote in the Mueller Report describes how Giorgi Rtskhiladze reported that he had successfully stopped the "flow of{{nbsp}}... compromising tapes of Trump rumored to be held by persons associated with the Russian real estate conglomerate Crocus Group" [owned by Agalarov].<ref name="Kessler_4/24/2019"/>

title: Steele dossier
added: A 25-second "pee tape" video of the purported occurrence has been in circulation since at least January 25, 2019. [[Ashley Feinberg]] has written extensively about it and all the reports and sources which have discussed and analyzed it. She describes it as believable but fake.<ref name="Feinberg_9/25/2019">{{cite web | last=Feinberg | first=Ashley | title=The Pee Tape Is Real, but It's Fake | website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2019/09/inside-the-convincing-fake-trump-pee-tape.html | date=September 25, 2019 | access-date=September 27, 2019}}</ref>

While many people, including Russians, do not believe the "pee tape" incident happened, [[Stanislav Belkovsky]], Russian [[political analyst]] and a founder and director of the National Strategy Institute, disagrees: "Prostitutes around the city say the 'golden shower' orgy story is true".<ref name="Nemtsova_1/20/2017">{{cite web | last=Nemtsova | first=Anna | title=She Met Donald Trump at the Moscow Ritz (Not That Way!) | website=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=January 20, 2017 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/01/20/she-met-donald-trump-at-the-moscow-ritz-not-that-way | access-date=December 1, 2019}}</ref>
